document.docTitle: Two new species of Dasybasis Macquart from the Peruvian Andes of Cusco (Diptera: Tabanidae: Diachlorini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Two new species of Dasybasis Macquart from the Peruvian Andes of Cusco (Diptera: Tabanidae: Diachlorini)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Instituto de Entomología, Facultad de Ciencias Básicas, Universidad Metropolitana de Ciencias de la Educación, Santiago, Chile.
Laboratorio de Entomología, Universidad Nacional de San Antonio Abad del Cusco, Cusco, Perú.

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Instituto de Entomología, Facultad de Ciencias Básicas, Universidad Metropolitana de Ciencias de la Educación, Santiago , Chile .
Laboratorio de Entomología, Universidad Nacional de San Antonio Abad del Cusco , Cusco , Perú .

subSection.paragraph:
Two new horse fly species,
Dasybasis mancoi
sp. nov. and
D. huaynai
sp. nov. ( Diptera : Tabanidae : Diachlorini ), are described from the Peruvian Andes near Cusco on the basis of morphological features, including those of the female genitalia. Digital photographs of both species and of the terminalia of both females and of one male are provided. The two new species are related to
D. bulbula Coscarón & Philip
, as evidenced by their similar morphological characteristics.

Key words: Horse fly , morphology , Neotropical Region , new species ,
Peru

Studies on Peruvian Tabanidae include those of Brèthes (1920) , Soukup (1945) , Philip (1960 ; 1961 ; 1969 ), Fairchild (1964) , Carrasco (1972) , Fairchild (1972) , Wilkerson & Fairchild (1984) , Goodwin (1999) , and Henriques & Krolow (2020) . However, the taxonomy of the tribe Diachlorini is still not completely resolved, and many groups still await study.

Morphological terminology used herein follows that of Cumming & Wood (2017) . The specimens were examined under a Nikon SMZ 1500 trinocular stereomicroscope. The “frontal index” is the ratio between the longitudinal length and the basal width of the frons. Terminalia were macerated in a 10% KOH solution at 50º C for one hour to dissolve the soft tissue. They were then neutralized with acetic acid, rinsed in distilled water, and dissected in 80% ethanol. Digital photographs were taken by use of a Nikon DS-Fi2 camera mounted on a Nikon SMZ 1500 trinocular stereomicroscope. Depth of the field was enhanced by use of Nikon ACT-2U software to stack multiple images.

Acronyms of depository institutions: UMCE (Instituto de Entomología, Universidad Metropolitana de Ciencias de la Educación, Santiago , Chile ), UNSAAC (Universidad Nacional de San Antonio Abad del Cusco , Perú ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality:
Peru , Sahuayaco ,
800 m
, Echarate , La Convención , Cusco
.

Description ( Holotype ♀ ) Female. Head.
Length 12.5 mm , wing length 11.5 mm . Body color grayish brown ( Fig. 1a, b ). Frons moderately wide, slightly convergent anteriorly, pruinose gray with short gray and black setulae, frontal index 2.4 ( Fig. 1c ). Basal callus light brown, subquadrate, with median dorsal projection extending more than half the height of the frons, touching subcallus, not touching the eyes ( Fig. 1c ). Eyes blackish with abundant minute gray ommatrichia ( Fig. 1d ). Ocellar triangle and ocelli absent. Vertex pruinose brown with short gray setulae. Subcallus ( Fig. 1c ) pruinose gray, without setulae. Parafacial and gena pruinose gray with abundant long gray setulae and a few short black setulae ( Fig. 1d ). Antennal scape brown with abundant long, erect, black setulae; scape 3X width of pedicel and 1.5X width of first flagellomere, globose and slightly concave on distal margin; pedicel orange, bearing short setulae on distal margin, without dorsal projection. First flagellomere blackish, with an obtuse angle, apical flagellomeres short and thickened ( Fig. 1e ). Maxillary palpus pruinose yellow gray; first segment rounded, yellow-gray with long grayish setulae; second segment 3X length of first, somewhat tapered, with blunt tip and with abundant long gray and black setulae ( Fig. 1f ); median side of palpus without setulae. Proboscis dark brown with yellow-black setulae; labellum large, fleshy, at the same height as head ( Fig. 1f ). Occiput pruinose gray with gray setulae on dorsal margin. Thorax. Scutum dark gray, bearing sparse short yellow-black setulae and four parallel longitudinal whitish stripes. Postpronotal lobes light brown with long black setulae. Scutellum dark gray, laterally with long yellow-black setulae, shorter on the disc. Pleura pruinose gray with long gray setulae; anepisternum with long gray and black setulae; katepisternum and katatergite with long gray setulae. Legs light brown, coxae with long gray setulae, femora with long gray and black setulae; tibiae darker, more setulose, setulae blackish gray; remaining leg segments with short black setulae. Wing slightly smoky and brownish in costal and subcostal cells, with clouds on R 1 , R 4 , and at bases of discal cell and M 1 ; R 5 and M 1 convergent; cell r 5 narrowed at the apex; veins Sc and R 1 with short black setulae; vein R 4 without appendix (
Fig. 1g
). Basicosta with short setulae. Halter brown, apex whitish. Squamae concolorous with wing base. Upper calypteres yellowish, lower calypteres lighter, with whitish setulae.
Distribution. Provinces of Calca and Urubamba ( Cusco ). Peru .

Type material.
Holotype ♀ : Sahuayaco ,
800 m
, Echarate ,
La Convención
, Cusco , PERU , R . Casafranca coll ( UNSAAC )
.
Paratypes : 1 ♀ San Pedro , Kosñipata [no other data] ( UMCE )
;
8 ♂ Kayra / S.J. , Cusco ,
3219 m
, 13°33’34’’ S 71°52’47’’ W ,
16/ Feb. /2002
, W.Alfaro coll. (7 UNSAAC , 1 UMCE )
;
1 ♂ Huatata ,
3610 m
, Chinchero / Urubamba / Cusco , PERU ,
22/Feb/2002
/ Juan F. Costa coll. ( UMCE )
.
Etymology. The specific epithet is in honor of the emperor Inca Manco.

Type locality:
Patabamba,
3940 m
, Calca , Cusco , Peru
,
Distribution. Known only from the holotype from the Calca ( Cusco ), Perú .

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype ♀ , Patabamba ,
3940 m
, Calca , Cusco ,
03.Jun.1992
, PERU , E. Yábar coll. ( UNSAAC ).

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The specific epithet is in honor of the emperor Inca Huayna.

subSection.paragraph:
Dasybasis mancoi
and
D. huaynai
exhibit generalized features characteristic of the genus
Dasybasis
: general color of the body grayish; eyes sparsely covered by ommatrichia and without bands; frons wide, rarely convergent at the base; basal callus quadrangular, touching eyes; ocellar triangle vestigial; ocelli vestigial; subcallus bare; antennae with pruinosity and without dorsal projection on basal flagellomere, scape variable in shape, pedicel generally with dorsal projection; maxillary palpi stout and short; scutum with longitudinal stripes reaching notopleural lobe; wings hyaline or with clouds on the veins, with short setae on Sc and R 1 with several rows of setae; abdomen with longitudinal stripes and with triangles on tergites ( Coscarón & Philip 1967 ; González 1999 ).

Dasybasis mancoi
is similar to
D. bulbula Coscarón & Philip
in general appearance (frons slightly convergent, basal callus touching eyes, scape globose, and mesonotum color), but
D. mancoi
differs in the following external characters: frontal index, eyes with very abundant ommatrichia, shape and color of frontal callus, subcallus bare, pedicel without dorsal projection, wings slightly smoky, without appendix on R 4 , basicosta bare, shape of gonapophysis, and genital fork with base convex ( Table 1 ).
Dasybasis huaynai
is also close to
D. bulbula
, but the latter differs in size, frons slightly convergent, basal callus shape, wing slightly smoky, and palpus with black and gray setulae ( Table 1 ). In addition to the characteristics mentioned, other differences among some species of
Dasybasis
are shown in Table 1 .

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Morphological comparison between the new species of
Dasybasis Macquart
and other species of the genus (N/I = no information).

tr.td: Rectangular, shiny black, top margin with irregular borders
Subtrapezoidal, with tufts of setulae at the base
Rectangular, upper edge with three extensions
Globose, 1.5 times the width of first flagellomere
Globose, slightly wider than the first flagellomere
Of the same width as the first flagellomere
Globose, of the same width as the first flagellomere
Globose, slightly wider than first flagellomere
Globose, slightly wider than first flagellomere
Dark gray with four longitudinal whitish stripes
Grayish brown with dark longitudinal stripes
Dark gray, with grayish longitudinal stripes

subSection.paragraph: We thank William L. Murphy, Research Collaborator with the Department of Entomology, National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington , DC, USA , for reviewing the manuscript and for help in editing the English version.
